Quoting Colin Green <locster01@...>:
> I was wondering what current users (user?) of SharpNeat would think
> about switching to a Java code base - David I know you're doing CPPN
> stuff, would a switch to Java be a major issue for your work? I guess
> you could continue on the existing code base anyway. Also IKVM
> (www.ikvm.net) allows you to use Java frameworks in a .Net environment
> - my only concern there though is there will be a slight loss of
> performance (but not that much).
>

On one hand, I'd have to rewrite distributed SharpNeat over again. This wouldn't
necessarily be a big deal, but in general .NET Remoting is much better than Java
RMI from a design level. Also, GUI development in Java is a horrendous ordeal
compared to VS and the resulting front end has a tendency to look like an OS/2
program.

On the other hand, I agree that Java is the preferred language for most research
nowadays, and the cross platform compatibility is a big plus. While I wouldn't
say that Eclipse is a dominant IDE compared to VS, you make a good point that
if you're broke/unfunded and don't have a student license then VS can't do much
for you. Additionally, I'm currently doing a software engineering MS with a
focus on Java tools, and being able to apply them to SharpNeat in a case study
in one of my papers would be fun.

Personally, I'd say if you can do it without requiring too many changes to the
API, go for it. At the end of the day, SharpNeat is a means to an end for most
people, not the end itself. Whether it's C# or Java, I think what most people
are interested in is really just the XML ANN that it produces.

> Oh and the other issue is that of support for generics/templates. Both
> Java and .Net have this now but in the Java world generics are still
> just language level constructs - they are not supported in the VM and
> hence there is no performance benefit(e.g. from avoidance of
> boxing/unboxing of value types), only a coding efficiency/compactness
> benefit. I understand this issue is being considered in the Java
> world, but it's not here now, today.
>

I wouldn't hold my breath on that happening. When generics were first being
discussed in Java, there were several proposed approaches, some of which did
modify the VM and the Bytecode language. Performance issues were discussed here
as well as reasons for doing it. In the end, the reason that they chose to make
generics only syntactic sugar was because if they modified Java Bytecode, they
would break countless legacy applications (hence the name of the paper, "Making
the future safe for the past"). Nevertheless, all that you're going to lose from
an efficiency standpoint is having to call CHECKCAST in the bytecode a few
times.  That's not a big deal.

Wesley
